author: arnetheduck
content: has anyone studied whether the attestations that get put into blocks actually are useful / make sense? ie every block right now has 128 attestations basically which slows down block processing and thus the network in general, but is it the case that all of those attestations cause some profit?

author: djrtwo
content: there are certainly entirely redundant attestations in there

author: djrtwo
content: I've checked just through manual inspection and regularly find strict subsets of other attestations in the same block

author: arnetheduck
content: well, they could still be profitable

author: djrtwo
content:
> slows down block processing and thus the network in general
That said, if 128 can't be handled efficiently (I'm pretty sure it can be), then that would be grounds for tuning constants

author: arnetheduck
content: well, it's 128 validations + 128*N public key aggregations

author: djrtwo
content:
_strict subsets_

meaning one attestation has validators [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] for vote A and another has validators [2, 3] also for vote A

author: djrtwo
content: that second attestation would not be profitable in the same block

author: djrtwo
content: if you included the second attestaion in block N and the 1st in block N+1 then it would be profitable

author: djrtwo
content:
> well, it's 128 validations + 128*N public key aggregations
yes, understood, so it will take longer, but if these large blocks "slow down the network" then we have a deeper problem with configuration choices

author: arnetheduck
content: sure - it's more that it eats into the security margin that we have, but there's no _direct_ economic incentive to not includde them

author: djrtwo
content: but agreed, if it were computationally hard to figure out a good packing, then it might be rational to just pack whatever and full

author: arnetheduck
content: not sure if it can be turned into an attack as well - I mean, it's actually interesting to see what the maximum number of operations is per block and then benchmark the libraries against that
